awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Ultra-Efficient Codes for Communication and Verifiable Storage
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to develop ultra-efficient coding schemes for modern communication and storage requirements brought forth by the pressing need to analyze and work with large amounts of data. A coding scheme is a means of protecting data from damage and loss. A desirable feature of coding schemes is locality, namely the property of being able to quickly recover a segment of the data by accessing only a tiny portion of a large data set. Other desirable properties include verifiability, which allows verification that data is properly stored, and privacy and security, which ensure that users' data is not misused. The outcomes of the research find application in distributed cloud storage. The communication schemes built in this research may be used in real-world deployment to ensure security of the transmitted message. Furthermore, the project aims to broaden participation in computing by involving undergraduate students in research, and by developing course material to introduce young children to basic concepts in coding theory and cryptography. The research will be broadly disseminated through presentations in workshops, seminars and conferences, and will be integrated in undergraduate and graduate courses at Purdue University.
 
The research project will focus on the study of local codes in probabilistic polynomial time channels, sequentially bounded channels, and power-bounded channels. It will also study local erasure coding schemes specific to distributed data, and develop novel cryptographic primitives to protect privacy and ensure robust storage of data. Specific outcomes of the research will include: (1) abstracting models that capture real-world data relevant to storage and communication; (2) providing ultra-efficient algorithms in these models; (3) incorporating privacy and security considerations; and (4) developing novel analysis techniques that  will integrate and advance diverse areas of mathematics and theoretical computer science including coding theory, sublinear algorithms, cryptography and privacy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A modern concern in dealing with large data is performing ultra-efficient computation, despite potential errors in the data, or despite other stringent requirements on real-world deployment, such as verifiability, which ensures that data is stored properly, and privacy and security, which ensure that data is used properly. The project addressed such challenges on several fronts. First, the research focused on building error-correcting codes with strong locality properties relevant to reliable and fast communication in several error models. Secondly, the research initiated a systematic study of sublinear-time algorithms that also preserve the differential privacy of individuals participating in the data.

The results from to the first direction consisted in several novel constructions of locally decodable codes, in the classical Hamming error model, insertion and deletion error model, as well as in models in which the adversary is restricted to bounded computational power. A locally decodable code is an error-correcting code where each bit of the transmitted message can be recovered by accessing only very few entries of the received word. The study of such codes in the presence of Hamming error has proved to be of fundamental importance throughout theoretical computer science over the past few decades. The main outcomes of this research consisted in strong lower bounds on the codeword length of insertion and deletion locally decodable codes, as well as fast algorithms in relevant parameter regimes. Such codes have direct applications in DNA storage biotechnologies.

The second direction of research resulted in differentially private algorithms that also run in   sublinear-time for fundamental combinatorial problems, including clustering problems, estimating the average degree of graph, and estimating the size of a maximum matching, among others. The research also investigated general frameworks for producing algorithmic results that satisfy both locality and differential privacy, starting with algorithms that only satisfy one of these features.

The project funded several PhD students who are now postdoctoral fellows in academia, or research scientists in industry labs.
